title: Sustainable Estates for the 21st Century: Furthering Landowner-Community Engagement
abstractText:
This project maximised the outputs of the ‘Sustainable Estates for the 21st Century’ project (SE21C). SE21C studied large estates in upland Scotland and focused on how landowners (private, charitable and community owners) influence those who live and work on the estate.

The research illustrated the impact of landowners’ decisions on community resilience and highlighted their role in facilitating business and lifestyle opportunities through sustaining rural employment and supporting community-generated entrepreneurship.

The aim of the Small Grant was to present and discuss research findings with landowners, estate managers, communities, policy makers and others who took part in the SE21C project, as well as others interested in the results.

Findings were presented at three feedback workshops in upland Scotland and an accessible reference booklet for practitioners was drafted for presentation at the events. The booklet focused on mutually-beneficial partnerships between privately-owned estates and communities, as well as more generic policy recommendations.

Workshop participants were asked to comment on the booklet and their feedback was  incorporated into the final version, which was published in June 2012. Findings were also disseminated through research seminars and stakeholder conferences, policy briefings, magazine articles and a project website.

findingsText:
1. An introduction to the research and policy contexts relevant to engagement and

collaboration around land use decision-making and sustainable rural communities



2. A summary of the key issues faced by rural communities in upland Scotland



3. Real examples of the benefits of engagement and collaboration between

privately-owned estates, community members and other partners



4. An analysis of the practical challenges that surround engagement and collaboration processes



5. A set of ‘ways forward’ and tools for addressing challenges and developing

‘win-win’ outcomes.



6. Three key messages that set out the implications of this booklet for estate

representatives, communities and other partners (including policy makers). The findings are of value to those who manage land/property and wish to improve their engagement with stakeholders (e.., comunities) - and vice versa. Communities and Social Services/Policy,Environment
